wiki.text:
started composing at age 5.]] A 'child prodigy' is someone who, at an early
 age, develops one or more skills at a level far beyond the norm for their
 age.<ref name="forbes.com"></ref> A prodigy has to be a child, or at least
 younger than 18 years, who is performing at the level of a highly trained adult
 in a very demanding field of endeavour.<ref name="forbes.com"/><ref>Feldman,
 David H: "Child Prodigies: A Distinctive Form of Giftedness", National
 Association for Gifted Children, Gifted Children Quarterly., 1993, 37(4): 188-
 193.</ref>

The giftedness of prodigies is determined by the degree of their talent relative
to their ages. Examples of particularly extreme prodigies could include Wolfgang
Amadeus Mozart and Teresa Milanollo in music, Magnus Carlsen, Sergey Karjakin,
Paul Morphy and José Capablanca in chess, Carl Friedrich Gauss, Srinivasa
Ramanujan, John von Neumann, and Terence Tao in mathematics, Pablo Picasso and
Wang Ximeng in art, Paul Thomas Anderson in film direction,<ref>http://www.totalfilm.com/features/greatest-directors-ever-part-
2.</ref><ref>http://movies.nytimes.com/person/231996/Paul-Thomas-
Anderson/biography</ref> and Saul Kripke in philosophy.<ref name="Charles
McGrath"></ref> There is controversy as to at what age and standard to use in
the definition of a prodigy.

The term 'Wunderkind' (from ) is sometimes used as a synonym for 'prodigy',
particularly in media accounts, although this term is discouraged in scientific
literature. Wunderkind also is used to recognize those who achieve success and
acclaim early in their adult careers.<ref name="Merriam-Webster
Dictionary"></ref>
wiki.title: child prodigy
